newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish senator sees 1997 tax vote on Thursday.
newsitem.headline: Polish senator sees 1997 tax vote on Thursday.

text.p: Poland's upper house, the Senate, will probably vote on whether to accept the lower house's 1997 income tax bill on Thursday, a senator from the leftist ruling coalition said.
"The Senate will most likely vote on taxes tomorrow," the head of the Democratic Left Alliance (SLD) party in the Senate, Ryszard Jarzembowski, told Reuters late on Wednesday.

Last month the lower house of parliament, the Sejm, unexpectedly passed a bill which envisaged the creation of a fourth income tax bracket for the lowest-paid, a scheme strongly opposed by the government.

The government, which has submitted a three-tax level plan of its own involving less radical tax cuts, says the Sejm bill is unacceptable because it would increase the budget deficit and lead to higher inflation.

Earlier on Wednesday, Finance Minister Grzegorz Kolodko hinted the government might accept one of two alternative three-bracket income tax proposals submitted to the Senate, although it still upheld its own plan.

After the vote, the Senate's decision on next year's tax bill is likely to return to the Sejm for a second reading before it is sent for signature by President Aleksander Kwasniewski, who has indicated he would veto a four-level tax bill should it again be passed by the lower house.
The tax levels have a crucial bearing on the main proportions of next year's budget, which the Sejm starts debating on Thursday.
